abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings convey a satisfactory project
            outcome, likely sustainability, but with only modest
            institutional development impacts. While the piloting nature
            of a Learning and Innovation Loan proved to be particularly
            appropriate in a new sector and an uncertain setting, where
            experimentation and testing of innovative approaches - i.e.
            especially in the Saxon village development - are essential,
            the selection process for pilot villages however, would have
            benefited from a more comprehensive community consultative
            effort earlier in the process, to include clearer selection
            criteria. In addition to reinforcing the need for community
            consultation and participation, established monitoring and
            evaluation mechanisms, and a strong supervision, several
            lessons are addressed as follows. Given the importance and
            uniqueness of cultural assets, and the patrimony regulations
            that govern their management and use in most countries,
            there are inevitable, and understandable clearance and
            approvals at various levels, that result in unexpected
            execution delays. The nature of these processes is
            significantly different from those experienced in most
            Bank-supported sectors; e.g., the processes involve several
            layers of review by art historians, restoration experts, and
            other specialists inside, and outside the Government. This
            factor must be taken more into account at the initial
            project design.

abstracts.cdata!:
The Cultural Heritage Project is to help
            Romania develop an improved national cultural heritage
            strategy that will preserve priority cultural heritage
            sites/assets by testing different partnership approaches
            with a view to improving overall management in a more
            sustainable, cost-effective manner. The project consists of
            four components. 1) The first component will support the
            renovation and restoration of the internationally acclaimed
            Brancusi Sculptural Ensemble. 2) The second component will
            help a) complete restoration of the 18th century Brancovan
            Palace at Mogosoaia; and b) finance emergency repairs and
            prepare a site development and management plan and community
            support program for a second Brancovan palace at Potlogi. 3)
            The third component will support a program to test pilot
            efforts in selected historic Saxon Villages in the central
            Transylvania region to determine options for sustaining
            cultural preservation and promoting social and
            inter-cultural cohesion. 4) The last component will assist
            institutional strengthening involving a) capacity building
            in the new project management unit in the Ministry of
            Culture; b) formulation of an long-term national cultural
            heritage partnership strategy; c) feasibility studies to
            determine the appropriate use of the new building for the
            National Library in Bucharest; and d) public information and
            awareness-raising campaign to build stronger civic
            understanding of the importance of cultural heritage.
